name: cycloguanil
Reason: The structure of cycloguanil (Clc1ccc(cc1)N2C(N)=NC(N)=NC2(C)C) consists of a substituted benzene ring and a triazine ring with amine and chlorine substituents. The base structure for comparison is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5 °C (39.1 °F). Each substituent will affect the melting point. The effects are as follows: Chlorine on benzene ring: raises melting point due to its electronegativity and increase in polarizability (+20). Each nitrogen in the triazine ring: has a significant electronic effect and capacity for hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point due to increased molecular rigidity and potential for intermolecular interactions. An individual nitrogen atom in a ring could contribute approximately +10 to the melting point. With four such nitrogens, this gives us a total of +40. Methyl group attached to triazine ring: adds to molecular weight, which tends to increase melting point, but the effect is smaller compared to other functional groups (+5). Overall the bulky triazine core provides stability and rigidity to the molecule, further raising the melting point. We can assume a general effect for the core (+50). So, the cumulative estimated increase in melting point is 5.5 (base benzene value) + 20 (chlorine) + 40 (nitrogens) + 5 (methyl group) + 50 (triazine core stability), which totals an estimated increase of 115.5.
